Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Emily Ruth McCarthy of William Marsh Rice University to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at Hongik Univeristy in Seoul, South Korea. The project title is "Improving the Seismic Reliability of Bridges with Innovative Shape Memory Alloy Devices." The host scientist is Dr. Eunsoo Choi.

Within transportation networks bridges are recognized as the most vulnerable links during earthquakes, with associated damage resulting in high repair costs and socio-economic disruption to the affected region. Through the use of innovative shape memory alloy devices, which can be strategically placed within an analytical bridge model, improvements in bridge reliability (i.e. the probability of survival) can be demonstrated for representative seismic events. Many existing methods for enhancing bridges' seismic resistance focus on developing components that activate in a single directional of motion while the device presented in this work aims to exploit the material's superelasticity effect to limit detrimental effects due to multi-directional displacements. The superelasticity effect most notably describes the material's ability to recover large deformations after application and removal of stress. Improved bridge reliability translates into increased public safety and long term reduction of related repair costs. Through fragility analysis, which describes the probability of failure of a system or component given a set intensity measure, the effectiveness of the proposed device to improve reliability is demonstrated.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the specific benefits of pursuing this research topic relate to improving public safety during seismic events and reducing post-event repair costs related to bridge damage. Additionally emergency responders requiring immediate connectivity between regions need functioning bridges and this maintenance of functionality can be facilitated through the incorporation of shape memory alloy devices in the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Development of an innovative shape memory alloy antiseismic device is motivated by the need to safe guard our bridge infrastructure and limit repair and replacement costs associated with seismic events. When earthquakes occur they can have long lasting effects on the impacted region in part through limited transport of goods, limited roadways for commuters, and limited access for emergency response vehicles. Especially when the functionality of critical lifeline bridges is diminished, the ability of a community to remain connected across waterways and canyons can be challenging, resulting in negative economic ramifications in addition to the loss of infrastructure and potentially human life. It is important therefore to efficiently design bridges so that they are equipped to withstand seismic events and have a level of post event functionality that meets the needs of the surrounding community.

Over the years many antiseismic devices have been researched, with a great deal of focus being given to base isolation of buildings and column design in bridges. It is widely recognized that the most vulnerable part of a bridge is the expansion joint between bridge segments. When excessive displacements are initiated by earthquakes, the bridge superstructure segments (those sections upon which traffic passes) move horizontally. When their movement exceeds that of the support length upon which they sit, the danger is that a segment will fall off its column support resulting in a tragic bridge failure. This failure is very dangerous for the public and impassable for emergency responders. The predominant methods of preventing this failure type are to add restraining cables as a retrofit of older bridges and to lengthen the support length of the bridge segments in newly constructed bridges. However the restraining cables are limited in that they do not act multi-directionally but are limited to acting axially only in the tension direction. The extended support lengths add no restraining but are necessary to be used in conjunction with a device that does restrain motion.

Some new devices being introduced into the bridge community offer multidirectional restraint against seismic displacements, however the materials they use require replacement after the occurrence of an event and do not accommodate recentering characteristics. Using instead an innovative shape memory alloy material that has the ability to recover deformations that are more than 30 times larger than traditional steel could introduce beneficial multi-directional recentering to the bridge system and thus lower life cycle costs and improve post-event functionality of the bridge system.

This work presents preliminary finite element data for a proposed antiseismic device using C-shaped SMA devices to limit displacements between bridge segments. Experimental data representing a ring shaped device is used to calibrate a model developed through the ADINA software program. Additionally using tensile data, which was heat treated via a similar procedure as the ring, the material model can, with a sufficient level of confidence, be used to model the C-shaped SMA devices. The resulting FEM analysis showed very good recentering characteristics for a C shaped device. Using fixed end constraints the device has good energy dissipative qualities, though the final design decided upon would use rotating ends to better accommodate a range of displacement degrees of freedom.
